Quantum mechanics is a mathematical theory, and it is important to understand its foundations. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum mechanics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that use both invertebrate and vertebrate hosts as part of their life cycle. Although the evolutionary origin of myxozoans has been elusive, a close relationship with cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids, is supported by some phylogenetic studies and the observation that the distinctive myxozoan structure, the polar capsule, is remarkably similar to the stinging structures (nematocysts) in cnidarians. Here, we present the first comparative analysis of the genomes of two myxozoans and a cnidarian, and show that myxozoans are a sister taxon to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, P. hydriforme. Our results suggest that the degeneration of the myxozoan body plan from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic parasitic cnidarian was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

The ability of viruses to evade the host immune response is a key factor in their ability to cause disease. In this study, we show that SARS-CoV-2 is able to efficiently block STAT1 and STAT2 nuclear translocation in order to impair transcriptional induction of IFN-stimulated genes (ISGs). Our results demonstrate that the viral accessory protein Orf6 localizes at the nuclear pore complex (NPC) and directly interacts with Nup98-Rae1 via its C-terminal domain to impair docking of cargo-receptor (karyopherin/importin) complex and disrupt nuclear import. In addition, we show that a methionine-to-arginine substitution at residue 58 impairs Orf6 binding to the Nup98-Rae1 complex and abolishes its IFN antagonistic function. All together our data unravel a mechanism of viral antagonism in which a virus hijacks the Nup98-Rae1 complex to overcome the antiviral action of IFN. This mechanism may be of great importance for the development of therapeutic strategies to combat COVID-19. (Show more)

Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of the proton channel Hv1, which is involved in many physiological processes. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. We propose that Zn2+ binding has two major effects on Hv1: (i) at low concentrations, Zn2+ binds to one site and prevents the opening conformational change of the pore of Hv1, thereby inhibiting proton conduction; and (ii) at high concentrations, Zn2+, in addition, binds to a second site and inhibits the outward movement of the voltage sensor of Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change will affect the global food supply, but the magnitude of the impact is uncertain. We use a statistical model to quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values, and the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year will increase substantially. Our results highlight the importance of investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

Herbivores are the primary agents of plant community assembly, and the diversity of herbivores is often thought to be a key driver of biodiversity. However, the extent to which different species of herbivores partition resources is largely unknown. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify the diet of multiple species of herbivores, even when they are matched in size and digestive physiology. We also show that different species of herbivores partition resources in ways that are not easily predicted from their body size alone. These results suggest that the diversity of herbivores may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. Our findings suggest that the COVID-19 crisis is already having a severe impact on small businesses, with many already laying off workers and closing their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey. Finally, many small businesses are planning to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of floating plastic on the open ocean is still unknown. We show that the plastic load on the open ocean is far less than expected, mostly due to size-selective sinks. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the elements is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The study of the origin of the elements is also of great importance for the understanding of the evolution of the universe. The study of the origin of the elements in the solar system is of particular interest because it provides information about the formation of the solar system.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This would increase the pressure on ocean resources.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is fatal within a few years after disease onset, and there is no treatment available to slow down the disease progression. Here, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765, which was well tolerated in a phase II clinical trial in patients with epilepsy, is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This suggests that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The endothelium is the lining of blood vessels and is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue. The endothelium is composed of thousands of specialized cells that are connected by a network of communication channels. The network is critical for the endothelium to control vascular function, but the nature of the communication system has been poorly understood. Here, the nature of the communication system has been addressed using single-cell Ca2+ imaging across thousands of endothelial cells in intact blood vessels. The findings reveal that the endothelial network design is effective for local and global efficiency in the interaction of the cells and rapid and robust communication between endothelial cells in order to efficiently control cardiovascular activity. The findings have implications for understanding the function of the endothelium and for developing new strategies for controlling cardiovascular function. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are being used to understand the spread of the disease, inform public health policy, and support research. However, the data are often difficult to access, and the information is often not available in a common format. We present the COVIDcast API, which provides open access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including many auxiliary indicators of public behavior. The data are available in a common format, and are updated daily. The data are available for researchers and policy makers, and we hope that the API will be useful in supporting the COVID-19 response.

Potassium channels are a large family of proteins that are involved in a wide variety of physiological processes. They are also the target of a large number of drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel, and it is the site of the ion selectivity. The activation gate is the site of the ion selectivity change. The coupling between these two domains is a key feature of the channel’s gating.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is essential for the health of the host. The gut microbiome is also highly dynamic, and the composition of the microbiome can be altered by the host, the environment, and the microbiota itself. The gut microbiome is also a source of natural products, which are compounds that have the potential to be used as pharmaceuticals. This study shows that anaerobic fungi, which are members of the gut microbiome, produce a variety of natural products. These findings support the idea that anaerobic fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. We show that anxiety, a personality trait that is known to influence social behavior, directly influences social dominance in rats. Moreover, we identify a key role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens in the development of social dominance. Our findings have important implications for the understanding of anxiety-related social disorders and for the development of new therapeutic approaches.

The ability to design and manufacture mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for a wide range of applications. However, the design of such devices is often limited by the complexity of the target behaviors and the material properties. Here, we propose a strategy to design and manufacture mechanical devices with arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses. The strategy is based on the synthesis of composite structures with multiple materials, which are digitally designed to achieve specific target behaviors. The synthesized structures are manufactured via multimaterial fabrication, and their highly nonlinear responses are physically and accurately realized in experiments. The proposed strategy can be extended to design and manufacture mechanical devices with complex and programmable behaviors.

The hemoglobin system is a key regulator of the timing of development in vertebrates. The hemoglobin system is also a target of the let-7 miRNA pathway. Here we show that the IGF2BP1 mRNA-binding protein is expressed in the developing human embryo and is downregulated in the adult. We show that IGF2BP1 can reverse the hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythroid cells, resulting in a fetal-like hemoglobin profile. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a key regulator of the timing of hemoglobin expression in humans.

Cancer is the number one cause of death worldwide. The development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we found that the inhibition of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis sensitizes cancer cells to ferroptosis induction, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation. This effect is mediated by activation of sterol regulatory element-binding protein 1 (SREBP1), a central transcription factor regulating lipid metabolism. In conclusion, the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction shows therapeutic promise in preclinical models. This approach may be useful for cancer treatment in the clinic. Hypertension is the most common cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is the cornerstone of the prevention of heart failure. The most common drugs for treating hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but they have side effects, such as dizziness, headache, and fatigue. We show that these drugs activate a pathway that promotes vascular remodeling.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy for the conservation of biodiversity in the Pacific Northwest. It was science-based, incorporated monitoring, and used adaptive management. We show that the NWFP was not successful in halting the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations. The policy’s success is also limited by the continued decline of older forests on federal land, which is now being affected by the recent fires.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. The development of new antibacterial agents is urgently needed to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. We present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. Our results demonstrate the potential of rational design to accelerate the discovery of new antibiotics. This approach can be extended to other antibiotic classes and to other targets. The design strategy presented here can be used to develop new antibiotics for the treatment of infections caused by antibiotic-resistant pathogens. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters, and is easier to train and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa (9–15° S). Over the Quaternary, we observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The use of electronic devices before bedtime is widespread in the United States and around the world. This study shows that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device before bedtime has important effects on sleep, performance, and health.

The Younger Dryas impact event is one of the most enigmatic events in the Earth’s history. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the event. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the Osmium isotope compositions of magnetic grains from the YDB sites in Arizona, Michigan, New Mexico, New Jersey, and Ohio are similar to average upper continental crust, indicating a terrestrial origin of Os in these samples. In contrast, the Osmium isotope compositions of bulk sediments from YDB sites in Belgium and Pennsylvania suggest mixing with extraterrestrial Os, but the Os in these samples is likely terrestrially derived.

CTLA-4 is a negative regulator of the immune response, but its specific role in the development of autoimmunity is not known. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to the development of a variety of autoimmunity, which is not fatal but can be ameliorated by the addition of CTLA-4-reexpression. This indicates that CTLA-4 is required for the development of autoimmunity, but not for the maintenance of tolerance.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles was driven by the codiversification of beetles and angiosperms, and that the evolution of their diet was shaped by the acquisition of genes that enable the digestion of plant cell walls.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the need for new vaccines and antiviral drugs. However, the emergence of variants with mutations that reduce or eliminate binding to antibodies has been a major obstacle to the development of such therapies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach that can be used to optimize the binding of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by optimizing the binding of an antibody that is effective against the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody is more than 10-fold more potent against the Delta variant than the original antibody. This approach can be used to optimize the binding of other antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially be used to develop new antibody drug candidates for the treatment of COVID-19. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work highlights the potential of deep learning to accelerate the development of new therapeutics. (Show more)

The evolution of technology is a fundamental topic in the study of evolution and the origins of culture. The extent to which larger populations enhance the evolution of technology is a key open question. We report the results of a large-scale experiment in which participants were exposed to different social-learning conditions, and the performance of the planes they constructed was measured. We found that larger populations did not enhance the evolution of technology, but that the size of the population was more important than the number of models that participants could learn from.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE4 may accelerate the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses, enhancing synaptic vulnerability to classical-complement-cascade mediated neurodegeneration.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is a key to understanding the origin of the Earth and the evolution of the planet. However, the formation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. We found that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of marijuana on the brain are well known, the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are not. Here, we show that chronic marijuana use is associated with reduced brain reactivity to methylphenidate, a drug that increases extracellular dopamine (DA). This reduced reactivity is associated with increased stress reactivity and irritability, as well as with increased addiction severity and craving. These findings suggest that the brain’s reactivity to DA stimulation may be a key factor in the development of marijuana abuse.

Language is a uniquely powerful form of communication, and the human capacity for language is one of the defining features of modern humans. However, the cognitive mechanisms of language comprehension are not well understood. Here, we show that the most powerful deep learning models of language processing are also the most accurate at predicting the next word in a sentence, and that these models’ predictions are strongly correlated with neural activity in the comprehension of the same sentences. These results provide computational evidence that the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain are being shaped by predictive processing. This approach may help to elucidate the neural mechanisms of language and other complex cognitive and social skills.

Deep learning (DL) has had unprecedented success in many areas of science and engineering. However, it is still an open question whether DL can be used in scientific computing, where the problems are often ill-conditioned. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm, even randomized, that can train (or compute) such a NN. Our results imply a classification theory describing conditions under which (stable) NNs with a given accuracy can be computed by an algorithm. We introduce fast iterative restarted networks (FIRENETs), which we both prove and numerically verify are stable. Moreover, we prove that only O(|log (ϵ)|) layers are needed for an ϵ-accurate solution to the inverse problem.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. It is also a scientific scandal. The scientific community is increasingly pointing to the failure of the general public to understand exponential growth as the main driver of the pandemic. This paper shows that the evidence for this claim is based on an experiment that was flawed from the start. It is argued that the study should be removed from the literature and that the scientific community should instead focus on designing better experiments.

Leprosy is a disease that has been studied for thousands of years. It is caused by two related bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which cause infection of the peripheral and central nervous systems, respectively. Here, we report the genome sequence of M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also show that M. lepromatosis is closer to the MRCA of the leprosy bacteria than is M. leprae, and that they have retained many of the same functions. Thus, despite their ancient separation, the two leprosy bacilli are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This work provides a foundation for understanding the evolution of leprosy and the mechanisms that have led to the development of the two distinct forms of the disease. The dynamics of entanglement in quantum many-body systems is a topic of great interest, as it is a key ingredient for the understanding of the emergence of thermodynamics. However, the dynamics of entanglement is a very difficult problem, as it is not amenable to perturbative or numerical treatments. Here, we show that the dynamics of entanglement in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This allows us to compute the dynamics of entanglement in the paradigmatic case of the Heisenberg chain.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global health emergency that requires a rapid development of a vaccine. Here, we describe the development of a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine, which is currently in clinical development. The vaccine is based on a recoded version of the SARS-CoV-2 genome, which is smaller and easier to manufacture than the wild-type virus. The vaccine is also temperature sensitive, which allows for the production of a large number of doses at room temperature. The vaccine is protective in hamsters, and the results of the first clinical trials in humans are expected soon. This vaccine has the potential to be used in mass vaccination programs. Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the Second Pandemic (14–19th centuries) is considered the most severe in Europe. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we propose a model for plague transmission by human ectoparasites, which has not been considered before. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks better than models for rodent or pneumonic transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353). This has important implications for our understanding of the history of plague in Europe.

The evolution of brain size is a key factor in the rise of complex cognition. However, the evolution of brain numbers, which are the basic computational units, has been neglected. We show that reptiles have not only small brains relative to body size but also low neuronal densities, resulting in average neuron numbers over 20 times lower than those in birds and mammals of similar body size. This has important implications for studies using relative brain size as a proxy when looking for evolutionary drivers of animal cognition.

Cancer is a complex disease, and the search for cancer targets is a long and difficult one. We have identified a role for TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein) in the regulation of metabolism and cell invasiveness. These findings suggest that TRAP1 may be a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main components of the cytoskeleton, which is essential for the function of all cells. They are also the main targets of the actin depolymerizing factor (ADF)/cofilin family of proteins. However, how ADF/cofilin acts on filaments in cells is not understood. Here, we show that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells. We find that the mechanical state of the filament, such as its curvature or twist, can affect the rate of severing. We propose a mechanochemical model that explains our observations. This model suggests that ADF/cofilin can sever filaments in a mechanical context, which is relevant to cells.

Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in place of glucose in processed foods. This study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater activation of brain regions involved in attention and reward processing and may promote feeding behavior. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on appetite and weight gain.

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, revealing a Bantu and Austronesian ancestry, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a recent demographic growth. Finally, we found that the genetic structure is influenced by geography, suggesting that a few centuries are enough to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar, which is a unique island in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions are influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This finding has implications for the design of social networks, as well as for our understanding of the psychology of social networks.

The presence of mRNA modifications is widespread in coding regions of messenger RNA, but the impact of these modifications on translation has not been well studied. We show that the presence of mRNA modifications can alter the rate of translation.

This study shows that the feeling that the things one does in life are worthwhile is associated with a wide range of positive health and well-being outcomes. This finding has implications for public health, as it suggests that promoting a sense of worthwhile living may be an effective way to improve the health and well-being of older people.
The evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg.

Rhinovirus is the most common cause of the common cold. It replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We show that mouse airway cells replicate rhinovirus more efficiently at cool temperature if they are primed for antiviral defense response. These findings have implications for the pathogenesis of rhinovirus infections in humans, which are more common in the winter, when the nasal cavity is cooler.

Bacteria are constantly exposed to their environment, and must be able to sense and respond to changes in the physical and chemical properties of their surroundings. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to detect the presence of surfaces. This mechanosensitive signal transduction pathway is required for the attachment of type IV pili to surfaces, and for the regulation of a large number of genes involved in virulence and biofilm formation. Our findings reveal a previously unknown role for type IV pili in sensing the physical properties of surfaces, and demonstrate that bacteria can use their appendages for sensing and signaling. This finding has implications for our understanding of the sensing capabilities of bacteria, and for the development of new strategies for controlling bacterial infections. The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the presence of pesticides in surface waters. We show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is a major threat to the quality of global water resources.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on the world, and the virus continues to spread. The role of animals in the transmission of SARS-CoV-2 is not fully understood, and the potential for the virus to persist in wildlife populations is of concern. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is widespread in North America. Our findings highlight the need for a “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This will be critical to understanding the potential for the virus to persist in wildlife populations and the risk of spillback into humans. Our study also provides a unique opportunity to monitor the evolution of the virus in deer, which could provide insights into the potential for recombination events that could lead to the emergence of new variants. This work highlights the importance of a coordinated and collaborative approach to study the ecology and evolution of SARS-CoV-2, which will be critical to mitigating the impact of the pandemic in the future. The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world for decades. The proliferation of large dams in the Mekong River Basin, the Amazon River Basin, and the Congo River Basin is a major concern because of the disruption of river ecology, deforestation, loss of biodiversity, greenhouse gas emissions, displacement of people, and changes to the food system, water quality, and agriculture. This paper examines the governance and compensation challenges, the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs, and the need to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the lack of effective treatments has led to a worldwide health crisis. The disease is thought to be caused by the accumulation of amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau in the brain, but the earliest events in the disease are poorly understood. Here, we show that soluble Aβ is the primary toxic species in neurons, and that they are the primary source of inflammation in the brain. This finding has implications for the development of new treatments for AD, as it suggests that targeting the Aβ-burdened neuron may be a promising approach.

The domestic chicken is today one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the question of when and where chickens were first used for economic purposes remains unresolved. We present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which show that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant during the Hellenistic period. We further show that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe predates the findings in the Levant by at least a century.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. We have developed a method that allows the study of the folding of a protein at high structural resolution. We have applied this method to the folding of maltose binding protein, a large protein that is known to fold through a native-like intermediate. The results show that the folding of the protein is a multistep process, with a fast step and a slow step. The fast step is the formation of a native-like intermediate, which is also the obligatory step.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been linked to the formation of caps on small RNAs. However, the role of Np4 in the degradation of those RNAs has not been explored. Here, we show that the decapping enzyme responsible for removing Np4 caps, inactivated by stress, preferentially degrades those RNAs. This finding has implications for the adaptability of bacteria to stress, as well as for the control of gene expression during stress.

Sepsis is a major cause of death worldwide. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We found that citrulline, a dietary amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a dietary supplement in the prevention of sepsis. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The biomass of the biosphere is the sum of the masses of all the organisms that inhabit the planet. It is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. Here, we provide a global census of the biomass of all kingdoms of life, showing that plants are the dominant kingdom, followed by animals, bacteria, and archaea. We also show that humans are the most abundant species on Earth. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humans on the biomass of prominent taxa. Our results provide a global view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and will be of interest to a broad audience of scientists and non-scientists alike.

We introduce a new model of self-organized criticality (SOC) that is continuous in contrast to all known models of SOC. We show that our model is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model, the first and archetypical model of SOC. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model (cf. Turing reaction-diffusion model), requiring further investigation.

However, diamond is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. For example, diamond is not a metal, and its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under thermal stress. The study of the structure and function of peptides is of great interest to the scientific community. The study of the antifungal activity of peptides is even more so. Here, we report the structure of a unique peptide, which exhibits antifungal activity against plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide can be used as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work will help to advance the development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungicide.

The male–female reproductive interface is the site of the most intimate interactions between gametes. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. We show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become more abundant on sperm after mating, suggesting that females contribute to the proteome of sperm during the period between mating and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work will be of interest to a broad audience of scientists interested in the molecular mechanisms of fertilization and the role of the male–female interface in reproduction. (Show more)

We show that force application to VWF switches the receptor to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for the pathophysiology of von Willebrand disease, the most common bleeding disorder. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive resource for the human virome, with over 45,000 unique virus taxa, and over 100 million viral sequences. The resource is available for use in future studies, and can be used to identify the presence of viruses in a variety of human samples.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the interaction process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to investigate ACI. The HSRL is able to measure aerosol and cloud properties simultaneously. We demonstrate the capability of the HSRL to investigate ACI. The results show that the HSRL can provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The origin of life is one of the most fundamental questions in science. The temperature of the surface of the early Earth is a key factor in the origin of life. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the early Earth.

Ion channels are the key regulators of ion flow and cell function. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. We found that the BK channel lacks a classic activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-type inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. C-type inactivation in most K+ channels occurs upon sustained membrane depolarization or channel opening and then recovers during hyperpolarized membrane potentials or channel closure. Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with over 200 million cases and 400,000 deaths each year. The parasite exploits a number of host cell signaling pathways to facilitate invasion of the red blood cell (RBC), the first step in the disease process. Here, we show that the parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) alters the biophysical properties of the RBC, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This finding suggests that the parasite primes the RBC surface, altering the physical properties of the cell, and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This would represent a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has implications for the development of new strategies for the control of malaria. (Show more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and chemical inertness. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, photonics, and quantum computing. However, diamond is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. For example, diamond is not a metal, and its electronic properties are not fully understood. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by applying strain. We also show that diamond can be demetallized by applying pressure. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. The seasonal increase in influenza virus transmission is associated with decreases in ambient humidity. However, the impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus transmission and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza infection. This may have implications for the development of strategies to control seasonal influenza epidemics. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic phrases as it processes a sentence. Whether and how this structure is represented in the brain is unknown. Here, we show that high-gamma power in multiple regions of the left hemisphere increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This merge operation is consistent with a bottom-up parser that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. Our results provide initial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This model of language processing may be a key to understanding the brain’s efficient representation of the structure of language. (Show more)

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and tissue homeostasis. It is also a target of cancer therapy. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level but differ in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are differentially regulated in different tissues, and that this differential regulation is important for the proper functioning of the pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem, and the mechanisms that regulate food intake are not fully understood. Here we show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces eating in sated mice. We also show that this stimulation is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area and the locus coeruleus. This system may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity.

Nitrogen is the most limiting nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of nitrogen in the soil is a major factor in the productivity of agricultural crops. The ability to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil would allow the delivery of nitrogen to the plant only when it is needed, thus improving the efficiency of the nitrogen cycle and the productivity of the crop. Here, we have developed a system that allows the control of the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil, and we have demonstrated that it can be used to control the nitrogen-fixing bacteria in the soil in a plant-specific manner. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This system could be used to improve the productivity of agricultural crops and to reduce the use of chemical nitrogen fertilizers. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

We study the impact of a community-based monitoring program in the Peruvian Amazon that was designed to reduce deforestation by facilitating transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities and incentivizing community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are surrounded by sound, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet all are made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of animals. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. Vaccine development has been accelerated, and several vaccines are now available. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. Here, we report the design and synthesis of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD protein that is suited for large-volume microbial production. This protein is well-suited for heterologous expression in bacteria, and the resulting VLP can be produced in large quantities. The engineered protein exhibits high affinity for ACE2, and antibodies raised against it exhibit heterotypic binding to the RBD from two variants of concern. This engineered protein may be a cost-effective and scalable vaccine candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.
We report the identification of a ligand–receptor pair that controls the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it, Yersinia pestis, has been responsible for some of the most devastating pandemics in human history. The earliest Y. pestis genomes recovered from the Neolithic period have revealed key evolutionary steps that led to its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor. However, the number of genomes recovered from this period are too few to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes dating to 5,000 to 2,500 y BP from a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results reveal a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period, a trend not observed in other pathogens for which ancient genomes are available. These data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election.

The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. However, the efficacy of soil health management practices in annual cropping systems on SOC storage in the long term remains highly uncertain. We show that soil health management practices that reduce soil disturbance, diversify crop rotations, and integrate livestock can increase SOC storage in the subsoil. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a framework for the development of climate-smart agricultural practices. This study also highlights the importance of long-term field experiments in understanding the long-term effects of agricultural management on soil health. This article is protected by copyright. The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a risk assessment framework to prioritize the risk of spillover and spread of wildlife viruses to humans. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting risk ranking framework and interactive web tool, SpillOver, can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This work provides a roadmap for the systematic identification of zoonotic threats and the development of strategies for their prevention and control.

Nectar is the reward that most plants offer to pollinators. The color of this reward is often an important factor in the success of the plant’s pollination system. Here, we show that the color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also show that this alkaloid is attractive to the vertebrate pollinator of this plant, the gecko Phelsuma geckos. This work provides evidence for the convergence of this trait in two other plants visited by hummingbirds. This work also suggests that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation.

We present a study of the genetic structure of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between the 5th and 6th centuries AD. Our results indicate that they had a very high genetic diversity, including signals of ancestry from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that some of them had artificial skull deformations, which may have been related to their genetic ancestry. Finally, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. We describe the use of a cloud-based metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) platform to investigate a large cohort of febrile patients in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in a patient before the national outbreak. This study highlights the potential of mNGS to rapidly investigate undifferentiated febrile illness in resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge. Coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study also highlights the importance of a global cloud-based platform for pathogen surveillance. The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the most important proteins is proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is a sliding clamp that allows DNA polymerase δ to replicate the lagging strand template. We have developed a unique set of assays to measure the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. The results indicate that the pol δ holoenzyme is not very processive and is very unstable. These results have profound implications for the replication of the lagging strand in humans.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In this paper, we report the first demonstration of the replication of genetic information in the absence of proteins.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is still unclear. The clinical manifestations of severe and critical patients are similar, and the mortality is high. The immune characteristics of patients with severe and critical COVID-19 are also similar. We have found that the treatment of tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathways, may be an effective strategy to reduce mortality.

Here we report the existence of a copper-binding natural product in fungi, and demonstrate the importance of this product in the maintenance of copper homeostasis and in the control of fungal growth. This work provides a new perspective on the role of natural products in the control of fungal growth and in the maintenance of homeostasis of essential micronutrients. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of SiO2, on Mars is surprising. The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary mudstone at the base of a crater wall/rim/central peak suggests that the sediment was deposited in a high-temperature environment. The diagenesis of the sediment was also likely influenced by the proximity of the sediment to a source of silicic volcanic material.

Frost damage is a major threat to the productivity of temperate and boreal forests, but the geographic distribution of frost risk and the evolutionary impact of frost events on trees are poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost risk is strongly related to the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings have important implications for land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a subset of CD4+ T cells that play a central role in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease are not fully understood. Here, we show that Th17 cells can contribute to the development of colitis by two distinct mechanisms. First, Th17 cells can directly transition to Th1-like cells, which are required for the development of colitis. Second, Th17 cells can support the development of classic Th1 cells from naïve precursors. These results suggest that Th17 cells are potent mediators of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a neurodegenerative disease with no cure. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients, enabling disease modeling and drug screening. This will accelerate the development of therapeutics for ALS.

The gut microbiota of arthropods is a complex community that plays a critical role in the health of the host. In this study, we show that the bacterium Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces the tick Ixodes scapularis to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the composition of the gut microbiota and enhances the ability of Anaplasma to colonize the tick. We demonstrate that iafgp binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These findings provide insight into the mechanisms by which a pathogen can influence the composition of the gut microbiota to enhance colonization of the vector. This work also highlights the potential for the use of arthropod antibacterial proteins as therapeutic agents. (Show more)

Birds are one of the most successful animal groups on Earth, and the origin of their characteristic short tail is one of the most important evolutionary questions in biology. Here, we report the discovery of a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, the pygostylians. This new taxon, named Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the evolution of the avian tail.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. We show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even in between. This color diversity is the result of the absorption of light by pigments in the skin. However, some vertebrates have a unique color, called chlorosis, which is the presence of green or blue tissues. Chlorosis is widespread in anurans, but its origin and function are unknown. Here, we show that the presence of chlorosis is the result of a mechanism that has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans. We also show that the mechanism is based on the presence of a group of serpins that bind biliverdin.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of metastasis. We report that hypoxia induces expression of ALKBH5, an m6A demethylase, which in turn regulates the expression of NANOG, a BCSC marker. NANOG expression is dependent on ALKBH5, and NANOG demethylation is required for the BCSC phenotype. Thus, ALKBH5 is a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer.

The Bible was the first book to be printed, and the first pocket Bible was produced in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age of the extinction is a key control on the timing of ecosystem recovery. The age model presented here is based on the age of the Global Stratotype Section and Point for the Permian-Triassic boundary at Meishan, China.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a group of chronic inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract. IBD is a complex disease with a high incidence, and there is no cure for it. The pathogenesis of IBD is complex and not fully understood. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays a crucial role in the intestinal epithelium (IE) and regulates the inflammatory response in IBD. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for IBD. This study also provides a new perspective for the treatment of IBD. (Show more)

We have determined the structure of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein in complex with the receptor, ACE2, and a lipid. The structure of the spike in complex with the receptor–ACE2 is a key step in understanding the mechanism of infection. The structure of the spike in complex with the lipid is a key step in understanding the mechanism of membrane fusion.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in the absence of the pandemic, life expectancy at birth would have been 78.65 y in 2020, and at age 65 y, 81.66 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings highlight the importance of addressing structural inequalities in order to reduce the burden of COVID-19 and improve health outcomes in the United States.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. They are also the key to understanding the origin of the chemical diversity of the elements. We show that the chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, decrease with pressure, and that the elements preceding Ni, Pd, and Pt become pseudo–noble-gas atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements right after them become highly electropositive. We show that our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales are able to explain and predict many chemical phenomena under pressure. This work is a major step forward in the understanding of the origin of chemical diversity. It also opens the door to the study of the chemical properties of atoms under extreme conditions, such as in the interiors of stars.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of wildfires, but the impact of this on the carbon cycle is uncertain. We show that, in some regions, changes in fire activity can reduce warming. This is due to the carbon stored in the soil being released to the atmosphere less frequently, and for a shorter time, than it would have been under a climate-only warming scenario. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to consider fire in climate change mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth of their symbiotic microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a mechanistic link between the provision of nutrients and the regulation of the activities of the microbiota in a host. It also suggests that other hosts may use the same strategy to regulate the activities of their microbiota. (Show more)

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need for methods to identify latent patterns is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. We draw on advances in theoretical machine learning to integrate topic modeling and word embedding, capitalizing on their distinct capabilities. Our method is illustrated with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This work is a step toward a more complete understanding of the social world.

The Black Death, the most devastating epidemic in human history, is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. We show that the climate in Asia was favorable for the survival of Y. pestis for several decades before the disease reached Europe. This suggests that the bacterium was introduced into European harbors via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. Our results provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. This indicates that the disease was not established in Europe until the end of the 1340s. Our findings have important implications for our understanding of the spread of the disease and the timing of the second plague pandemic. (Show more)

Asteroids are a group of organisms that have been studied for decades, but the recent discovery of a disease that has led to the death of thousands of individuals has led to a renewed interest in these animals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus and that it is transmitted by starfish.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia in adults, and the prognosis of patients is poor. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. Here, we show that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, from the north to the south, and from the east to the west. We find that Madagascar is a unique island, with a unique history.

Bacteria are able to respond to a wide variety of environmental changes by altering the expression of their genes. This is accomplished by a variety of mechanisms, including small RNAs. These RNAs are found in all domains of life and are thought to be noncoding. However, a few have been found to encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the need for new vaccines and antiviral drugs. However, the emergence of variants with mutations that reduce or eliminate binding to antibodies has been a major obstacle to the development of such therapies. Here, we introduce a deep learning approach that can be used to optimize the binding of antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding of an antibody that is effective against the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody is more than 10-fold more potent against the Delta variant than the original antibody. Our approach can be used to optimize the binding of other antibodies to SARS-CoV-2 variants and potentially be used to develop new antibody drug candidates for the treatment of COVID-19. This approach can also be applied to other protein molecules. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of new therapies for COVID-19.

Crop experts are the backbone of the agricultural sector, providing information on crop status and condition to the government and the public. However, the information provided by crop experts is often qualitative and subjective, making it difficult to use for quantitative analysis. We show that the information provided by crop experts can be transformed into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used for quantitative analysis. We demonstrate the utility of this approach by developing a Crop Condition Index that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. The proposed approach can be extended to other crops and countries, and can be used to monitor the status of other natural resources such as forests and fisheries.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to store and integrate information over short periods of time. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in neuronal excitability. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the length of time that information is stored. This mechanism is not dependent on synaptic plasticity or persistent activity, and it is not limited to a single neuron. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community. However, despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The origin of plastids and the evolution of their genomes are key questions in the origin of life. The transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is a major event in the evolution of plastids, but the molecular signature of this transition is not well understood. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner.

The 2015–2017 rainfall deficit in southwestern South Africa was the worst in more than a century. We show that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of this event by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 5-8.5). This highlights the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. The results also show that the risk of drought in SSA is increasing, and that the current drought is likely to be the first of many in the future. This will have severe consequences for the region’s water supply and food security. The results are relevant to other regions that are vulnerable to drought, such as the southwestern United States, Australia, and southern Africa. This article is protected by copyright.
