The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has revolutionized the study of materials, and the discovery of quasicrystals in the aftermath of the first nuclear explosion has revolutionized the study of time.

Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth, and the light-dependent reactions are powered by the capture of solar energy. The chlorophyll pigments are the key intermediates in this process, and the formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the so-called cyclase reaction, is the rate-limiting step. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes, which have remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. Here, we show that the two enzymes are part of a single protein family, and that the different classes of the enzyme are evolutionarily conserved. These data provide a framework for understanding the evolution of the cyclase reaction. (Show more)

Neuroinflammation is a major cause of neurodegenerative diseases, and neuroinflammation is known to be regulated by mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase, ASK1. However, the precise roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unknown. Here, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in neuroinflammation, and that ASK1 in astrocytes plays a role in the later stage of neuroinflammation. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in glial cells may be a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of neuroinflammation in neurodegenerative diseases. (Show more)

The 2012–2014 drought in California is the driest on record. We find that the probability of drought years has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is likely due to human activities.

Autism is a complex disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the autism-risk genes and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work is the first to our knowledge to examine the prevalence of negativity biases in news content across a large, representative sample of the world’s population. Results show that, on average, people around the world are more likely to react negatively to news content than positively. This work accordingly helps account for the tendency for news around the world to be predominantly negative. It also highlights the potential for more positive content, and suggests that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ homeostasis. In this study, we identify mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and the pore-forming protein ORAI1 that result in a spectrum of phenotypes, including hematological abnormalities, bleeding diathesis, and muscle dysfunction. These data expand our understanding of the molecular basis of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, and suggest new therapeutic approaches for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The spread of protein aggregates throughout the brain is a key feature of several major neurodegenerative diseases. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are not well understood. Here we show that the spread of aggregates in a Drosophila model of Huntington’s disease is dependent on endocytosis and that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1. These findings provide insights into the mechanisms of spreading in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Bats are the most diverse group of mammals and are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. MTX inhibited the antiviral responses of the host and facilitated viral infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. The findings also highlight the importance of understanding the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to prevent future zoonotic disease outbreaks. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2 (SHMT1/2). This inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and is particularly effective in B-cell cancer cell lines. We show that the inhibitor is effective in vivo because it is effective in vitro, and that the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity is enhanced by a deficiency in glycine import. Thus, the inhibitor is effective in vivo because it is effective in vitro, and in vitro because it is effective in vivo. This is a simple, elegant, and powerful principle for cancer therapy.

The presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusion bodies in the brain and spinal cord of patients with ALS suggests that the disease is associated with a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons. This metastable state is likely to be the result of a progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this setting.

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic, and the origin of this group is poorly understood. The study of Montsechia, an early flowering plant from the Cretaceous, opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution and that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages.

The evolution of viruses is of great interest to the scientific community, as well as to the general public. However, the study of viruses in the past is difficult because of the lack of viral genome preservation in ancient samples. Here we present the genomes of five individuals who lived between ∼0.5 and ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya, and we are able to date the recombination event between genotypes 1 and 3 that formed genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 kya. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level around the world has been rising steadily for the last century. However, the rate of rise has accelerated in recent decades. This acceleration is due to the combined effects of climate change and the elastic rebound of the Earth’s surface in response to the removal of the stress from recent earthquakes.

Pain is a major public health problem, and the number of Americans reporting pain is rising. However, the elderly are not reporting more pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase is more rapid for those born after 1950. This pattern is consistent with the erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950, and may have important implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate provides a detailed picture of the structure and reactivity of a key enzyme intermediate. This study highlights the power of the integrated application of solid-state NMR, X-ray crystallography, and first-principles computational chemistry to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme catalysis. The study also demonstrates the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography in the study of the mechanism of a reaction that does not proceed via the formation of a covalent bond. This work is expected to have a broad impact on the field of enzymology.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe human coronavirus that has caused a recent resurgence of cases. There is no specific antiviral treatment, and the high case fatality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is currently in clinical trials for the treatment of Ebola virus disease, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This suggests that remdesivir may be a useful treatment for MERS, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This would be of benefit in the context of a clinical trial of remdesivir for the treatment of MERS. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to microbes is a common strategy used by animals to regulate the growth of their symbiotic microbiota. However, the mechanisms by which this occurs are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its luminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, by the strategic delivery of a single glycan, chitin. This glycan is catabolized by the symbionts only at night, when the squid is producing light, and is required for the maintenance of a healthy symbiosis. This study provides a mechanistic link between the provision of nutrients and the regulation of the activities of the microbiota in a host. It also suggests that other hosts may use the same strategy to regulate the activities of their microbiota. (Show more)

Suspension rates in the United States have risen sharply in recent decades, with the most dramatic increases among students of color. This study shows that teachers can be trained to adopt a more empathic mindset about discipline, which can be sustained through a brief online intervention. This intervention halved suspension rates in a randomized field experiment, and bolstered the respect of suspended students for their teachers. These findings have implications for the future of American education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription process is sensitive to the presence of DNA alkylation. In particular, the transcription process is sensitive to the location of the alkylation. The results from the present study provide important mechanistic insights into the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis. This work also provides a foundation for the development of new strategies for cancer therapy. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. Fusion occurs only after S proteins are cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. To more precisely determine how sequential proteolysis contributes to CoV infection, we introduced S mutations obstructing the first cleavages. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, precleaved MERS viruses used receptor-proximal, cell-surface proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry, whereas the more rigid uncleaved MERS viruses trafficked past these cell-surface proteases and into

The food system is responsible for a large share of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the population have a major impact on the environment and on population health. This study shows that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals served in a catering environment can have a large impact on meal selection. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell with the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of six oncogenes, including EGFR, HER2, KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a major step forward in understanding the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome, and the role of oncogenes in remodeling the cell surface. This work also provides a platform for future studies of the cell surface proteome and glycoproteome in normal and cancer cells.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a policy that can be implemented with minimal costs and that it is unlikely to have significant effects on electoral outcomes.

SARS-CoV-2 is the cause of the COVID-19 pandemic. The role of the viral accessory protein ORF8 in the disease is unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which reveals a unique dimerization interface not present in SARS-CoV. This finding, combined with the rapid evolution of the protein, suggests that ORF8 may be involved in immune evasion and/or interference with the host antiviral response. These activities are of great interest in the fight against COVID-19. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the mechanisms underlying this process are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this process is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus, which acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1. This leads to an increase in the expression of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and endothelin-1 (ET-1) and to an increase in water influx into astrocytes, which in turn leads to edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema induced by hypobaric hypoxia. This knowledge may be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of cerebral edema. (Show more)

The scientific enterprise is in the midst of a revolution. The amount of data being generated is growing exponentially, and the sophistication of the statistical methods being used to analyze these data is growing exponentially as well. This paper addresses a fundamental challenge in this new era: How do we properly assess the strength of associations that we find in the data?

The development of vascular networks is a key step in the regeneration of organs. In this study, we found that ets variant 2 (ETV2) can directly induce the formation of vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETVECs can form mature vascular networks in vivo. This study provides a new approach for the regeneration of organs. It also provides a new strategy for the treatment of vascular diseases. This study will be of great significance for the treatment of vascular diseases and the regeneration of organs.

We report the discovery of a third class of RTKs, the augmentor RTKs, which are involved in the development of the zebrafish eye and skin. This discovery is made possible by the use of zebrafish as a model system.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a major public health problem. Although the molecular basis of T2D is well known, the mechanisms of insulin resistance and β-cell dysfunction remain to be further elucidated. Herein, we found that STING, a key molecule in the interferon pathway, plays a critical role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function. STING deficiency in β-cells caused a loss of nuclear factor of activated T-cells 1 (NFAT) and Pax6, leading to impaired GSIS. These findings provide a molecular mechanism for the role of STING in the regulation of insulin sensitivity and β-cell function, which may be useful for the development of new therapeutic strategies for T2D. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Influenza A viruses are responsible for an annual influenza epidemic and occasional severe pandemics. Their genome is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The existence of a selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, such as hypertension, diabetes, dyslipidemia, and obesity. The development of atherosclerotic lesions is a highly dynamic process that is regulated by a variety of factors, including local hemodynamic environment. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. Our results demonstrate a critical role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis. Therefore, inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone phenotypes and atherogenesis, which may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. (Show more)

Wildfires are a natural part of the Earth system, but they can also be a threat to human communities and property. The economic and ecological costs of wildfire in the United States have risen substantially in recent decades. Although climate change has likely enabled a portion of the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We evaluate government records of wildfires that had to be extinguished or managed by state or federal agencies from 1992 to 2012, and examine geographic and seasonal extents of human-ignited wildfires relative to lightning-ignited wildfires. Humans have vastly expanded the spatial and seasonal “fire niche” in the coterminous United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: the density of college-educated adults, the initial appearance of the neighborhood, and the proximity of the neighborhood to other attractive neighborhoods. These results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a sustainable alternative to synthetic pesticides. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the perception of natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study provides a molecular basis for the evolution of natural repellents in arthropods and highlights the potential of sTRP1 as a target for the development of novel insect control strategies. It should also help the conservation of biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with fetal abnormalities and neurological complications, prompting global concern. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of plasma ZIKV burden in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We estimate that the eclipse phase for ZIKV, the time between cell infection and viral production, is most likely short (∼4 h), the median within-host basic reproductive number R0 is 10.7, the rate of viral production is rapid (>25,000 virions d−1), and the lifetime of an infected cell while producing virus is ∼5 h. We also estimate that the minimum number of virions produced by an infected cell over its lifetime is ∼5,500. We assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication, showing that the median time to undetectable plasma viral load can be reduced from ∼5 d to ∼3 d with a drug concentration ∼15 times the drug’s EC50 when treatment is given prophylactically starting at the time of infection.

Coral reefs are in the midst of a mass bleaching event, which is driven by anthropogenic warming of the oceans. The breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a major consequence of this breakdown, but the underlying causes remain unclear. Here, we show that the metabolic state of the coral host is a key factor in the onset of the breakdown of the symbiosis. We demonstrate that the catabolism of amino acids is a major driver of the metabolic energy demand of the coral host, which is compensated by the degradation of the coral’s own organic compounds. The resulting shift from net uptake to release of ammonium by the coral holobiont promotes the growth of algal symbionts and retention of photosynthates. Together, these processes form a feedback loop that will gradually lead to the decoupling of carbon translocation from the symbiont to the host. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help uncover fundamental processes underpinning the functioning of endosymbioses in general. The intestinal epithelium is a complex tissue that regulates the absorption of nutrients, the mounting of immune responses, and the prevention of systemic infections. In this study, we show that the epithelium is also a tumorigenic tissue. We identify a mechanism by which the epithelium can be transformed into a tumor, and we show that the tumorigenesis is coupled to the dysregulation of the microbiome. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of the JNK pathway to maintain the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. It also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis. This work has implications for the development of cancer therapies. (Show more)

Chemotherapy is the most common treatment for breast cancer, but the response of a patient to chemotherapy is unpredictable. We found that the expression of the orphan receptor ROR1 was up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. ROR1 expression was associated with the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, which are involved in the regulation of breast cancer stemness. ROR1 expression also enhanced the capacity of breast cancer cells to metastasize or reengraft mice. Treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (truncated)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies, but this is not supported by a unique, volcanic eruption-driven climate event.

Freshwater fisheries are a major source of animal protein, recreation, and commerce in many regions of the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which can be used to assess the impacts of fishing on biodiversity and food security. Our data highlight the importance of inland fisheries for nutrition and poverty alleviation, and the need to protect their biodiversity.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2 delivers a large capacity of ∼170 mA ⋅ h ⋅ g−1 with a low operating potential range of 1.9 to 2.8 versus Li/Li+ in 21 m lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)amide (LiTFSA) aqueous electrolyte. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅

The ability to regenerate is a fundamental property of the nervous system. In the adult mammalian CNS, however, neurons are unable to regenerate in response to injury. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway, which is the major pathway known to mediate regeneration in the adult CNS. This discovery has implications for the study of regeneration in the adult CNS, as well as for the development of regenerative therapies.

The process of DNA recombination is fundamental to the functioning of the genome. It is also the target of many human diseases. In this study, we describe the distribution of recombination in the genome of a flowering plant, the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus. We find that the distribution of recombination is highly similar to that in yeast and in mice, suggesting that the process of recombination has been conserved in evolution.

The resting state network (RSN) hypothesis has been proposed to explain the functional organization of the human brain. However, the RSN concept is based on the analysis of fluctuations in functional MRI signal, representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. Here, we show that metabolic imaging, which maps nonfluctuating signals related to total neuronal activity, can be used to identify and validate reproducible RSN topographies in healthy and disease populations. In addition, we show that the RSN concept can be used to assess the functional status of the brain, and that this approach can be used to monitor the progression of neurodegenerative diseases. This approach can be extended to the study of the functional organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is found on all nuclear and mitochondrial mRNAs. Here we report the discovery of a second 5′ modification, the nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) cap. We show that NAD-mRNA is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs in yeast. NAD-mRNA appears to be produced cotranscriptionally because NAD-RNA is also found on pre-mRNAs, and only on mitochondrial transcripts that are not 5′ end processed. This finding suggests that the NAD-cap could modulate RNA stability and translation on specific subclasses of mRNAs. The discovery of the NAD-cap provides a new example of the diversity of 5′ modifications in eukaryotes.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive vs. conventional therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in people with diabetes. We found that DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years during the follow-up of people with diabetes. These epigenetic changes are associated with glycemia and may contribute to the metabolic memory phenomenon.

This study provides evidence that FSIP1 is a potential therapeutic target in TNBC. We show that FSIP1 is highly expressed in TNBC and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, which in turn, leads to inhibition of mTOR and Wnt/β-catenin signaling. These effects, in turn, contribute to the sensitivity of TNBC cells to chemotherapy drugs. Thus, our findings may aid in the design of therapeutic strategies for TNBC. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high social and economic impact. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, which may be related to the development of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving. Moreover, the composition and activity of the gut microbiota are altered in alcohol-dependent subjects, suggesting that the gut microbiota is involved in the development of alcohol dependence. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthesis of these compounds is not known, and the role of nitrogenous volatiles in tomato flavor is not understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylation reactions to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in a wide range of disciplines. (Show more)

We show that the impacts of global warming on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are more complex than previously thought. We demonstrate that the effects of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning are mediated by changes in the thermal tolerance of species. Our results highlight the importance of considering the thermal tolerance of species when assessing the impacts of climate change on ecosystem functioning. This is critical for understanding the impacts of biodiversity loss on the functioning of ecosystems, and for predicting the consequences of climate change for the provision of ecosystem services.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure for navigation. It contains a large population of neurons that fire in a place-dependent manner, and the precise organization of these neurons is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of a large number of neurons in freely behaving mice. We found that the spatial organization of place cells is different from that of other neurons in MEC. These data provide a basis for further studies of the functional organization of MEC. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that flowering of the host is required for flowering of the parasite. This is an example of a unique means of flowering regulation in which the flowering of the host is used by the parasite to synchronize its own flowering.
The dopamine systems of the brain powerfully influence movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of the nigrostriatum form specialized integrative units within the system.

We all have a sense of whether we are connected to others. But how do we know when two people are connected? We show that the speed with which people respond to each other is a robust predictor of felt connection. This signal is used by others to assess connection, and it is used by people to assess connection.

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also known as the “clock of the heart” because it is the only cardiac region that generates electrical activity in a rhythmic manner. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) and Orai1 channels, key components of store-operated Ca2+ entry, are selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN. Cardiac-specific deletion of STIM1 in mice resulted in depletion of sarcoplasmic reticulum (SR) Ca2+ stores of the SAN and led to SAN dysfunction, as was evident by a reduction in heart rate, sinus arrest, and an exaggerated autonomic response to cholinergic signaling. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in the SAN that links SR Ca2+ store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the molecular mechanisms that govern the heart rate and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. (Show more

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant resistance against biotic and abiotic stresses have been well documented. However, the role of silicon in mediating plant resistance against insect herbivores has not been explored. Here, we show that silicon pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that silicon may be used as a biocontrol agent to enhance plant resistance against insect herbivores. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the interaction between silicon and JA in plant defense. (Show more)

The lipidome of macrophages is a complex and dynamic system, which is involved in a wide range of physiological and pathological processes. The present study reveals a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages. The results also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ether lipids in the immune system and may be of interest for the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Language is a complex system that requires the ability to integrate and store information over time. Here we propose a mechanism that supports memory in the brain. We show that the dynamics of the neuronal membrane potential can be decoupled from the underlying firing rate. This allows for the storage of information in the form of adaptive conductances that reduce the firing rate. We demonstrate that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and can support the binding of linguistic features over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic compounds or to find nutrients. Thus, they have evolved a defense mechanism to protect themselves from pathogens. This defense mechanism is triggered by the presence of a pathogen, which leads to the production of a set of defense proteins. These proteins are toxic to the plant and are used to kill the pathogen. However, these proteins are also toxic to the plant itself, and thus, the plant has evolved a defense mechanism to protect itself from these proteins. Nutrient loading from small tributaries of large water bodies is often overlooked, despite their ubiquity and potential importance. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit high nutrient loads for their size and bias toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that their plumes become trapped and then overlap in the nearshore zone, increasing the likelihood of coastal eutrophication. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in driving coastal nutrient loading, and they provide a framework for understanding the relative importance of different watershed sizes in driving nutrient loading to large water bodies. This approach could be applied to other large water bodies to identify the relative roles of small and large tributaries in driving coastal eutrophication.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is able to provide work to the system only in rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the behavior of complex networks, where the long-time dynamics of the system are biased toward states that are highly connected in the network. Our results suggest that the dynamics of complex systems may be biased toward states that are highly optimized for the environment in which they evolve.

We show that NMDA-receptor antibodies (NMDAR-Abs) can cause a wide range of paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We also show that NMDAR-Abs can change the intrinsic properties of the brain, which can alter the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity. Finally, we show that these changes can be predicted by a dynamic model of the brain. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Abs. This work may help to identify patients who are at risk of developing paroxysmal EEG abnormalities and may also lead to the development of new therapies. This article is protected by copyright. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2 million y. The cause of this warming is still debated, but it is likely due to a combination of natural and anthropogenic forcings. Here, we present evidence for a similar warming event that occurred ∼304 Ma, which was likely caused by a natural forcing. This event is important to understand because it occurred during a glacial period, when the Earth system was already in a state of reduced greenhouse warming.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO). However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. We show that certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil. Certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation.

The exocyst complex is responsible for the final steps of exocytosis, which is essential for the release of proteins from the transiting vesicle. The exocyst complex is composed of 10 evolutionarily conserved subunits. The function of the exocyst complex is conserved from bacteria to humans, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex is a key component of sex differences in development and behavior. In this study, we investigate the effects of multiple sex determination alleles on the evolution of secondary sexual characteristics in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii. We find that the interaction of multiple sex determination alleles can produce a modular system of sexual polymorphism, where the same trait can be sexually dimorphic in some individuals and monomorphic in others. This system of sexual polymorphism may be a general feature of sex determination, and may be important for understanding the maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations.

The retina is a unique organ that is challenged by two distinct types of reactive oxygen species. One set of species, generated by the metabolism of vitamin A, is targeted by the antioxidant network. The second set of species, generated by photooxidation of the retinal pigment epithelium, is targeted by the photoreceptor cell. We show that the levels of iron in the retina impact the balance between these two sets of species.

Predators are the key drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is a central topic in ecology. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that the evolution of specialization in siphonophores is not only possible, but also linked to the evolution of morphological innovations. Our findings have implications for understanding the evolution of predatory feeding strategies, and for predicting the effects of climate change on marine food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolution. This study provides the earliest evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process.

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus metabolic targeting is a promising cancer therapy. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule dual inhibitor of serine hydroxymethyltransferase 1/2 (SHMT1/2). This inhibitor is effective in vitro and in vivo, and is particularly effective in B-cell cancer cell lines. We show that the inhibitor is effective in vivo because it is effective in vitro, and that the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity is enhanced by a deficiency in glycine import. Thus, the inhibitor is a promising lead for the development of cancer therapeutics. This work is a step toward the development of metabolic cancer therapeutics. Deforestation is a major driver of environmental change, and the loss of natural landscapes is a key contributor to the global nutrition crisis. This study shows that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets, and that this can be mitigated by the presence of natural forests. The results have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of natural landscapes in meeting nutrition goals, and the need to include them in strategies to improve food and nutrition security.

Modern farm machinery is responsible for the majority of soil compaction, which is a major threat to soil productivity. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to a significant increase in subsoil compaction, which now exceeds safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We also show that the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods. This suggests that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. Our findings have important implications for the future of agriculture, as well as for the study of the past. (Show more)
